page.lettertext:
fol.29r
Belgia 1591 st
i
Ro
m
16 January To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Ja
n
May it please yo
r
good L. wher as petition hath bin made
to the
generall states
for the encreasing of the forces
of these contreys w
th
an extraordinary levy of 3000 foote
& 300 horse to bee emploied in the field for 7 monethes
the same is urged continually by the
Councell of
State
, And besides they are in hand w
th
a new
Remonstrance, for the reducing of every cornet of horse
in their paie, w
ch
are commonly now of 70 horse
to
e nomb
r
of 120. They have also determined to
crave her Ma
ties
assistance for the like augmentation to bee
made in
e english horsband
. for the effecting wherof
both the Councell &
Count Maurice
have entreated mee
earnestly, to hold a good hand in their behalf, & to
accompany theyr sute, w
th
my private letters to her
Ma
ty
.
The alleage unto mee for yt, that her Hig
nes
forwardnes
therin, will move her Provinces sooner to passe their assent
& though the surcharge in 4 cornets, for 7 monethes
will mount to very littell for her Ma
tyes
portion, yet in
computation of
e whole, the renforcement will rise to a
round encrease, w
th
all they are in hope, that although
their proposition to
e States doth specifie but 7 moneths
yet when their purpose is obtained, they shalbee able
by
swasion, to continew them still in the self same state.
For answer wherunto I lett them und
r
stand, how
excessively & w
th
out intermission her Hig
nes
is charged
w
th
e warres of these countreys, w
th
relieving the
French
K.
w
th
disbo
r
sing of her treasure for the germaine levies,
w
th
fournishing her shippes to anoy the ennemy by sea,
& sondry oth
r
waies for w
ch
I could not bee
swaded shee
would willinglie enter into a farder charge, especially heer
where her Ma
tie
they see doth continually
test against
theyr ingratitude. Nevertheles being one of their
assembly, I would not refuse to joyne my letters w
th
theirs, & to bee as earnest in their causes as conveniently
I might, my duty respected. And as I am often
bold upon my wonted confidence in yo
r
honorable liking
to saie my opinion to many thing
, so I thinke it not
im
tinent to signifie in this, that though her Ma
ty
bee
not willing, as I p
r
sume shee is not, to hearken to their
fol.29v
To my L. Treasuror Ja
n
16. 90.
Belgia: 1591: Ja
n
motion, yet it will bee very requisite, to entertaine the
Councell for a time, in some litell kinde of hope of
obtaining their sute. for they will use yt as a meanes
to drawe the generality to a greater contribution, for
the foresaid levies, & besides as I writ in my former,
two daies past yf her Hig
nes
bee resolved to send some
te
of her forces to
e aide of the f
r
King, when the country
is
vided of these new supplies, the w
th
drawing of
her subject
wilbee lesse offensive to this people, & not
so hurtfull to their cause as yt is greatly to bee
feared yt might otherwise prove. But yo
r
L. knowing
theyr demaund will easily conceave what awnswere ys
fittest,
w
ch
refer accordinglie to yo
r
L. wisdome, & take
my humble leave. Ja
n
16. 90. Fr
o
e Hague
.
